page.title: 17COAL IN THE AMMANFORD AREA
page.content: Ammanford stands on the northwestern edge of the South Wales coalfield. The seams are very folded and broken but the high quality of the anthracite coal has always made it in demand. It was the coal that attracted many poeple into the area 200 years ago. The little village was then called "Cross Inn". People moved to Cross Inn to find work in the many mines, like the Butchers mine at Betws and the Gelly Ceidrim at Glanaman. Railway lines were built to carry the coal from the Amman and neighbouring valleys to the port of Llanelli. Most of the old mines have now closed. One large drift mine operates at Betws and there are several open cast sites, (eg. at Saron), but most of the jobs in the coal mines have disappeared in the last 40 years.
